ari.ucd

Class UCDWordList

  • java.lang.Object
    • ari.ucd.UCDWordList
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<UCDWord>

    public class UCDWordList
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<UCDWord>
    Object listing and ordering alphabetically a set of UCD words.

    Searching UCD words

    This object behaves like a dictionary. It is possible to search UCD words in different ways:

    • For a specific UCD word: get(String) (namespaces ignored), get(String, boolean)
    • For all UCD words starting with a given string: startingWith(String)
    • For a UCD word with some typographical errors: getClosest(String)
    • For UCD whose the description (and also the word's atoms) matches some keywords: search(String)

    Import from a file

    A list of UCD word definitions can be imported from a PSV (Pipe-Separated-Value) file using addAll(File), addAll(File, boolean), addAll(InputStream, boolean) or addAll(Reader, boolean). The first function will import all identified UCD words as NOT recommended. If you want to change this behaviour, use addAll(File, boolean) instead.

    Version:
    1.0 (02/2017)
    Author:
    Grégory Mantelet (ARI)

      • addAll

        public int addAll(java.io.File psvFile)
           throws java.lang.NullPointerException,
                  java.io.IOException
        Add all UCD words declared using the PSV (Pipe-Separated-Value) format inside the specified file.

        The real parsing is performed by UCDParser.parseWordList(Reader, boolean, UCDWordList). Please take a look to its Javadoc for more details about the expected syntax and the possible errors that can occur.

        Note: This function will import all UCD words as NOT recommended. If you want to import them as recommended, use addAll(File, boolean) instead with the second parameter set to true.

        Parameters:
        psvFile - PSV file to parse.
        Returns:
        The number of successfully added UCD words extracted from the file.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the given file is null.
        java.io.IOException - If an error occurred while reading the specified file.
        See Also:
        addAll(File, boolean)

           throws java.lang.NullPointerException,

        Add all UCD words declared using the PSV (Pipe-Separated-Value) format inside the specified file.

           throws java.lang.NullPointerException,

        Add all UCD words declared using the PSV (Pipe-Separated-Value) format inside the specified reader.

        Returns:

      • get

        public UCDWord get(java.lang.String ucdWord)
        Search for an exact match with the given UCD word but while ignoring their namespace.

        Important note: Comparisons are case INsensitive and the namespaces are ignored.

        Warning: If this function returns a UCDWord, it may have a different namespace than the one of the given UCD word. To search on the word AND on the namespace you should use get(String, boolean) or apply a final test on the namespace of the returned word.

        Parameters:
        ucdWord - The UCD word to search.
        Returns:
        The corresponding UCDWord instance matching the given UCD word, or null if the given word is null, an empty string or can not be found in this list.
        See Also:
        get(String, boolean)

      • get

        public UCDWord get(java.lang.String ucdWord,
          boolean checkNamespace)
        Search for an exact match with the given supposed UCD word.

        Important note: Comparisons are case INsensitive.

        Parameters:
        ucdWord - The UCD word to search.
        checkNamespace - true to ensure the namespace of the match is the same as the one of the given word, false to search only on the word and not check the namespace.
        Returns:
        The corresponding UCDWord instance matching the given UCD word, or null if the given word is null, an empty string or can not be found in this list.

      • getClosest

        public UCDWord[] getClosest(java.lang.String wrongWord)
        Search for a UCD word the closest as possible from the given one.

        This function aims to help fixing typo in a given UCD word. It uses the Levenshtein algorithm to determine the UCD word of this list which requires the fewest number of editions (i.e. add, replace and remove a character) to match the given word.

        This function is designed to select UCD words with a number of required editions less or equal to half the length of the given word. Consequently, smaller is the given word, smaller are the probabilities to find a closest match in this list. In other words, this function should not be used for small words (e.g. less than 3-4 characters).

        Note 1: It is entirely possible that several words have the same distance from the given word. In such case, this function will return all candidates in an array.

        Note 2: Search is performed case INsensitive and the namespaces are ignored.

        Parameters:
        wrongWord - The word to fix.
        Returns:
        List of all the closest UCDWords from the given UCD word.

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<UCDWord> iterator()
        Let iterate (by alphabetic order) over the whole list of UCD words.

      • lev_min

        protected static int lev_min(int a,
          int b,
          int c)
        Compute the minimum value among the three given one.

        This function is used only by levenshtein(String, String) ; hence its name.

        Parameters:
        a - A value.
        b - Another value.
        c - A last value.
        Returns:
        The minimum of a, b and c.

      • levenshtein

        protected static int levenshtein(java.lang.String left,
              java.lang.String right)
                          throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Compute the Levenshtein distance between the two given strings.

        Short definition of the Levenshtein algorithm by Wikipedia:

        In information theory and computer science, the Levenshtein distance is a string metric for measuring the difference between two sequences. Informally, the Levenshtein distance between two words is the minimum number of single-character edits (i.e. insertions, deletions or substitutions) required to change one word into the other.

        This function has been strongly inspired of the Java code source provided on http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Levenshtein_distance#Java

        Parameters:
        left - A first string. Must NOT be NULL
        right - A second string. Must NOT be NULL
        Returns:
        The distance between the two given strings. 0 is a perfect equality ; max(left.length, right.length) is a perfect difference.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If one of the given string is null.

        public UCDWord remove(java.lang.String ucdWord)

        Returns:

      • search

        public java.util.Set<UCDWord> search(java.lang.String keywords)
        Search for all UCD words whose the description matches the given keywords.

        Important note: Comparisons are case insensitive.

        Parameters:
        keywords - String concatenating (with space characters) some keywords.
        Returns:
        A set of UCD words whose the description matches the given keywords. This set is ordered by descending score.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
